papers.abstract: In this article, I outline a method of combining ethnography and computational soundscape analysis in order to listen to processes of gentrification in Washington, DC. I utilize Kaleidoscope Pro, a software suite built to visualize and cluster bioacoustic recordings (typically birds and bats) to cluster points of tension in the soundscape of Shaw, a rapidly gentrifying neighborhood in DC. Clustering and visualizing these sounds (which include car horns, sirens, public transportation, and music) makes audible the sonic markers of gentrification in Shaw. Furthermore, listening to gentrification is a call to engage with the sonic right to the city, histories of legislating sound, and sonorities of memory and nostalgia. This work contributes to the burgeoning black digital humanities canon by thinking through how computational methods can help us to hear black life. Although the digital humanities have turned to embrace the sonic in recent years, there is still much to be done in considering how to embrace the aural in DH work. This project invites us to listen closely to a changing neighborhood and emphasizes sound as a valid mode of knowledge production, questioning how a sonic rendering of gentrifying space through the digital might move us toward more equitable soundscapes.

events.Text: In this article, I outline a method of combining ethnography and computational soundscape analysis in order to listen to processes of gentrification in Washington, DC.

Primary Object: a method of combining ethnography and computational soundscape analysis in order to listen to processes of gentrification in Washington, DC

Context: in order to listen to processes of gentrification in Washington, DC
Purpose: to provide insights into the mechanisms driving gentrification through the integration of qualitative and quantitative methodologies

events.Text: I utilize Kaleidoscope Pro, a software suite built to visualize and cluster bioacoustic recordings (typically birds and bats) to cluster points of tension in the soundscape of Shaw, a rapidly gentrifying neighborhood in DC. Clustering and visualizing these sounds (which include car horns, sirens, public transportation, and music) makes audible the sonic markers of gentrification in Shaw.

Primary Object: sonic markers of gentrification in Shaw
Secondary Object: various types of noise including car horns, sirens, public transportation, and music

Context: Clustering and visualizing these sounds (which include car horns, sirens, public transportation, and music) makes audible the sonic markers of gentrification in Shaw.
Purpose: To investigate the impact of gentrification in Shaw
Method: Using Kaleidoscope Pro, collect and analyze audio data comprising car horns, sirens, public transportation, and music.
Results: They were able to detect hallmark features indicative of gentrification.
Implications: This allows urban planners to better understand and address the transformation of neighborhoods undergoing gentrification.

events.Text: Furthermore, listening to gentrification is a call to engage with the sonic right to the city, histories of legislating sound, and sonorities of memory and nostalgia. This work contributes to the burgeoning black digital humanities canon by thinking through how computational methods can help us to hear black life.

Primary Object: a call to engage with the sonic right to the city, histories of legislating sound, and sonorities of memory and nostalgia

events.Text: Although the digital humanities have turned to embrace the sonic in recent years, there is still much to be done in considering how to embrace the aural in DH work. This project invites us to listen closely to a changing neighborhood and emphasizes sound as a valid mode of knowledge production, questioning how a sonic rendering of gentrifying space through the digital might move us toward more equitable soundscapes.

Primary Object: sound as a valid mode of knowledge production

Implications: This project emphasizes sound as a valid mode of knowledge production and questions how a sonic rendition of gentrifying space through the digital might move us toward more equitable soundscapes.

By inviting us to listen closely to a changing neighborhood and focusing on sound as a form of knowledge production, this initiative challenges traditional narratives surrounding gentrification and explores innovative ways to create equitable public spaces through auditory means.

papers.abstract: Studying collaboration in music is a prominent area of research in fields such as cultural studies, history, and musicology. For scholars interested in studying collaboration, network analysis has proven to be a viable methodological approach. Yet, a challenge is that heterogeneous data makes it difficult to study collaboration networks across music genres, which means that there are almost only studies on individual genres. To solve this problem, we propose a generalizable approach to studying the topological properties of music collaboration networks within and between genres that relies on data from the freely available Discogs database. To illustrate the approach, we provide a comparison of the genres Jazz and Hip Hop.

events.Text: Studying collaboration in music is a prominent area of research in fields such as cultural studies, history, and musicology. For scholars interested in studying collaboration, network analysis has proven to be a viable methodological approach. Yet, a challenge is that heterogeneous data makes it difficult to study collaboration networks across music genres, which means that there are almost only studies on individual genres.
events.Main Action: has proven to be a viable methodological approach

Context: There are almost only studies on individual genres.
Purpose: To expand beyond individual genre analyses to comparative studies across diverse music forms.
Method: Network analysis has proven to be a viable methodological approach.
Results: Despite its promise, network analysis faces challenges when attempting to compare collaboration networks across multiple music genres.
Analysis: Heterogeneous data complicates meaningful comparisons between genres.
Challenge: Almost all studies on collaboration networks are confined to individual genres.
Implications: Improving network analysis methods could pave the way for more comprehensive studies of collaboration across music genres.

events.Text: To solve this problem, we propose a generalizable approach to studying the topological properties of music collaboration networks within and between genres that relies on data from the freely available Discogs database. To illustrate the approach, we provide a comparison of the genres Jazz and Hip Hop.

Secondary Object: to studying the topological properties of music collaboration networks within and between genres
